Project Description

The Project will decentralize management and improve the quality of health
services delivery particularly to the poor and vulnerable groups. The Project
will be implemented in two phases in 50 districts and 12 cities of 7 provinces:
Aceh, Bali, Bengkulu, Central Sulawesi, North Sulawesi, Riau, and Southeast
Sulawesi.  In  the  first  phase,  activities  will  concentrate  on  developing  local
capacity to plan, manage and deliver health services. Local governments and
health  offices  will  prepare  health  sector  development  plans  and  investment
proposals  to  improve  service  quality,  efficiency,  and  effectiveness,  and
proposals to introduce locally appropriate health sector reforms. In the second
phase,  the  Project  will  support  the  implementation  of  technically  and
economically  justified  proposals  that  address  the  priority  needs  of  the  poor
and vulnerable groups.

Primary: Human development
Secondary: Poverty reduction

Where  new  facilities  are  constructed,  an  environmental  impact  assessment
and environmental management and monitoring plans will be prepared before
the  subproject  proposal  is  approved.  With  expected  improvement  in
sanitation,  the  overall  impact  of  the  Project  on  the  environment  will  be
positive.

Implementation of decentralization will start in early 2001, in accordance
with  the  laws  on  decentralization  voted  in  May  1999.  Decentralization
offers  opportunities  to  better  answer  local  health  needs  through  locally
adapted reforms and specific investments in the health sector. However,
rapid  implementation  of  decentralization  could  create  a  major  risk  of
breakdown  in  the  delivery  of  public  health  services  because  the
traditionally  centralized  planning  and  management  of  health  services
have not prepared local staff adequately to take over this responsibility.
There is a need to support local health staff during the transition period
and  prepare  them  for  their  new  responsibilities.  While  assisting  local
governments  to  maintain  health  services  delivery,  the  Project  will  help
local  governments  identify  local  needs,  giving  priority  to  programs  that
target and benefit the poor, and improve health service quality.

The  objectives  are  to  strengthen  local  capacity  in  health  services
delivery,  including  planning  and  management,  to  ensure  continuous
access to quality health and family planning services, particularly by the
poor; and to improve quality, cost-efficiency, and sustainability of health
and family planning services in the project area. Advocacy, training, and
technical  support  will  first  build  up  local  governments’  commitment  and
capacity.  Subsequently,  the  Project  will  help  districts  and  provinces
implement appropriate health sector reforms and support investments to
better address the needs of the poor and vulnerable groups and improve
services quality, efficiency, and effectiveness.

Poor and vulnerable groups in the project area will particularly benefit from
the Project. The Project will facilitate continuous availability of quality health
services  during  the  difficult  period  of  transition  to  decentralization.
Investments and reform proposals from the districts will address the needs
of the local poor. Capacity-building activities will benefit not only health staff
but also other members of the civil society. The Project aims at a minimum
of 50 percent women among the beneficiaries of the training activities.

decentralization,  resulting  in  lack  of  clarity  and  understanding  of  the
new roles and responsibilities of the various levels and institutions. The
weak  capacity  of  the  district  and  provincial  staff  due  to  the  traditional
centralized  system  will  be  addressed  through  intensive  capacity-

The  health  status  of  the  Indonesian  population  gradually  improved  over  the  last  three
decades. The infant mortality rate for example declined from 145 infant deaths per thousand live
births in 1970 to 40 in 1999.6 However, the maternal mortality rate (MMR)–estimated between
390 and 450 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births–is among the highest in the region and is
very high by international standards.7 While most health and nutrition indicators have improved,
Indonesia’s  health  indicators  remain  disappointing  compared  with  those  of  neighboring
countries.8  Moreover,  such  gains  were  uneven  and  significant  differences  remained  between
regions and provinces, between urban and rural areas, and especially between the rich and the
poor.  Although  cardiovascular  and  chronic  diseases  became  the  main  cause  of  mortality  in
1992, infectious and parasitic diseases dominate morbidity and are still a major cause of deaths,
affecting  particularly  the  poor.  Tuberculosis,  malaria,  respiratory  infections,  and  diarrhea  are
major public health issues. In the 1980s and early 1990s, the Government made serious efforts
to develop a network of health facilities and ensure physical access to health services all over
the  country.  This  policy  was  relatively  successful  in  achieving  physical  targets:  the  average
distance to a health center or a hospital is 5 kilometers (km) in rural areas and 1.5 km in urban
areas.  But  the  use  of  health  services  (bed  occupancy  rates  in  hospitals,  outpatient
consultations)  has  been  low,  at  least  in  the  public  sector,  suggesting  low  client  satisfaction.

Indonesia  has  developed  a  successful  family  planning  program,  organized  by  BKKBN.
6. 
With its slogan “Small Happy Family,” BKKBN advocates birth spacing and small families, and
ensures  availability  of  modern  methods  of  contraception  all  over  the  country,  resulting  in  a
significant contraceptive prevalence rate (at 57.4 percent in1997). The average number of births
per woman during her childbearing age (i.e., the total fertility rate) declined from 4.1 in 1985 to
2.5 in 1999, and the annual population growth rate steadily decreased from 2.2 percent in 1985
to 1.7 percent in 1993. BKKBN is centrally organized and managed with a hierarchy down to the
subdistricts. Policy and programs are developed, monitored, and evaluated at the central level.
BKKBN village volunteers provide general information on contraception in their community, and
support  contraceptive  users  (reminding  for  example  pill  users  not  to  forget  their  daily  pill).
BKKBN field-workers advocate family planning in the community, supervise village volunteers,
and  collect  field  data  for  monitoring  and  evaluating  the  program.  MOHSW  health  center  or
district  hospital  staff  are  responsible  for  medical  examinations  and  interventions  (providing
injections,  inserting  intrauterine  devices).  Although  the  relatively  narrow  scope  of  the  family
planning  program  (compared  with  MOHSW  programs)  makes  implementation  less  difficult,
some  features  of  the  program,  particularly  its  flexibility  and  results-oriented  approach,  have
probably  contributed  to  its  success.  Different  targets  are  established  for  each  province,  and
different  program  components  are  emphasized,  taking  into  consideration  the  local  social,
political,  and  economic  conditions.  BKKBN  has  also  been  relatively  successful  in  mobilizing

health  services  are  available  and  offer  quality  services.  In  many  rural  areas  and  less  favored
urban  areas,  religious  and  other  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  usually  not  for  profit,
have set up health centers and sometimes small hospitals for the local populations, often filling
gap coverage or complementing the public sector. In 1998, 40.7 percent, 52.7 percent, and 4.5
percent  of  the  population  were  using  public,  private,  and  traditional  health  care  services,
respectively (SUSENAS data). Unfortunately, public and private sectors have been developing
and  functioning  in  parallel,  with  very  little  coordination  and  cooperation,  except  in  family
planning,  where  BKKBN  strongly  supported  the  demand  for  and  provision  of  private  family
planning services for those who could afford them.

9. 
Total expenditure for health is low, increasing slightly from 1.0 percent of gross domestic
product  (GDP)  in  1995,  to  1.2  percent  in  1998.  As  a  percentage  of  total  Government
expenditure, health expenditures varied from 2.9 percent in 1985, 3.3 percent in 1995, and 2.9
percent  in  1998.  Regardless  of  the  Government’s  commitment  to  the  health  sector,  the
economic downturn reduced available resources. In real terms, Government health expenditure
declined  by  16.5  percent  between  1995  and  1998.  Out-of-pocket  payments  by  households
declined from 69 percent of total health expenditure in 1995 to 42 percent in 1998 reflecting, in
part, more limited household resources. The difference was covered by an increase in external
support.  The  Government  has  committed  to  allocate  at  least  3  percent  of  the  FY2000  budget
and at least 4 percent of the FY2001 budget for health, nutrition, and family planning programs.
Chronically low funding of public health services affects service quality and effectiveness, which
in  turn  have  an  impact  on  the  use  of  public  health  services  and  the  health  status  of  the
population.

2. 

Constraints and Issues

10. 
The health service delivery system, managed centrally from Jakarta, no longer answers
adequately  the  needs  and  the  demand  of  the  local  populations.  Despite  relatively  satisfactory
physical  coverage,  given  the  geographic  and  climatic  constraints,  health  indicators  have  not
improved as rapidly as those in neighboring countries. Relatively poor health service quality in
the  public  sector  affects  service  utilization12  and  effectiveness.  There  is  a  need  to  rehabilitate
and  upgrade  some  facilities  and  improve  medical  equipment,  both  for  diagnostic  and  curative
purpose.  Besides  insufficient  financing  and  insufficient  attention  to  local  needs,  major  issues
relate  to  the  lack  of  local  personnel  sufficiently  qualified  in  health  service  management  and  to
structural and organizational issues.

11. 
A consequence of a centrally managed health system is a generally weak management
capacity  at  the  local  level.  With  some  exceptions,  local  health  staff  have  been  trained  to
implement  instructions  but  not  to  take  initiative  and  responsibility.  Health  workers  have  been
required  to  apply  centrally  developed  instructions,  often  without  clearly  understanding  why.
Their  performance  is  evaluated  based  on  process  indicators  rather  than  outputs:  a  certain
number  of  reports  must  be  filled,  and  national  programs  request  regular  data  on  program
activities. The impact of these activities on health and nutrition status is not the responsibility of
local staff. Health indicators are collated and analyzed at the central level with little feedback on
results to local staff.

resources  reached  the  targeted  communities  and  probably  protected  the  populations  from  a

sharply.  With  aggressive  outreach  programs  to  identify  pregnant  women  and  to  provide

provinces doubled. The decline in nutritional status among pregnant women and young children
was  arrested  by  mid-1999  and  has  improved  since.  Overall,  utilization  of  health  services  and

1. 

Health Policy and Services

The  1999  state  guidelines  provide  guidance  for  health  sector  policy.  To  improve  the
24. 
quality  of  human  resources  and  the  environment,  the  Government  will  emphasize  health
promotion  and  prevention  of  diseases,  in  combination  with  curative  services,  recovery,  and
rehabilitation. For better quality health institutions and services, staff will be developed, facilities
and infrastructure improved, and affordable medicines supplied. Particular attention will be paid
to  the  poor,  neglected  children,  disabled,  elderly,  and  socially  vulnerable  groups.  Controlling
population growth and raising the quality of the family planning program remain high priority.

Healthy  Indonesia  2010,  developed  in  1999,  describes  MOHSW’s  vision,  strategy,  and
25.

healthy  living  behavior,  and  obtain  qualified  health  services  that  are  effective,  efficient,  and
evenly  distributed.  People  must  be  actively  involved  in  maintaining  and  promoting  health,
preventing diseases, and protecting themselves from them. Efforts will focus on four areas: (i)
cross-sectoral cooperation, (ii) health staff and public empowerment, (ii) quality and accessibility
of  health  services,  and  (iv)  prioritization  and  funding  of  health  activities.  Cross-sectoral
cooperation is important to ensure a healthy environment. Professional management of health
services with participation of the community will determine the success of the policy. The health
policy should prioritize health promotion and maintenance, and disease prevention. Funding for
health activities should increase, especially for health maintenance and promotion; and curative
and  rehabilitative  activities  need  to  be  financed  more  by  society.  This  will  require  the
development  of  an  efficient,  equitable,  and  participatory  health  prepayment  system  and  better
collaboration  with  the  private  sector.  MOHSW  has  defined  four  priority  strategies:  national
development  with  health  concerns,  better  professional  qualification,  strengthening  health

 2. 

Decentralization

9

26. 
Although decentralization has been on the political agenda for many years, adoption by
the Parliament in May 1999 of Law 22 and Law 25 sharply accelerated the process. The laws
provide  a  broad  framework  and  define  the  timetable:  decentralization  of  the  Government’s
services  and  functions  must  be  implemented  in  2001,  transferring  major  management,
administrative,  and  fiscal  responsibilities  mainly  to  the  districts.  District  authorities  and  district
parliaments  (DPRDs)  will  be  directly  responsible  for  identifying  local  needs,  addressing  local
issues,  choosing  locally  suitable  solutions,  mobilizing  necessary  resources,  and  implementing
appropriate  decisions  and  plans  of  action.  In  addition,  all  functions  that  are  not  specifically
assigned  in  Law  No.  22/99  to  central  and  provincial  levels  automatically  belong  to  districts.
Although  the  legislation  provides  the  broad  framework  for  decentralization,  implementation
plans have not been finalized, with many regulations still in draft or under discussion, including
regulations  on  (i)  transfer  of  civil  servants,  assets,  and  spending  authority  to  the  districts;  (ii)
fiscal  transfer  and  revenue-sharing  arrangements  required  to  finance  transfer  functions;  (iii)
guidelines  for  local  government  borrowing;  (iv)  accountability  of  local  governments,  financial
management, and budget procedures; and (v) financial information system.

27. 
Under decentralization, the roles and functions of the central MOHSW will be limited to
formulating the national health policy and plans, and assisting the local governments to achieve
nationwide objectives through resource mobilization and allocation. More specifically, MOHSW
will  set  national  standards  and  guidelines  on  nutrition,  medical  education,  food  and  medicine
quality and distribution, and provincial and district planning, and it will monitor the performance
of districts and provinces on critical indicators. Districts and provinces will receive block grants
from  the  central  Government,  and  will  be  responsible  for  managing  their  own  health  planning
and  budgeting  to  reflect  local  needs  and  priorities  and  to  provide  community-oriented  health
services.

Local governments will have more control over finances, planning process, civil service
28. 
organizations,  and  cooperative  bodies.  Central  ministry  representative  offices  in  the  provinces
and  districts  will  be  absorbed  into  local  government  structures  under  the  governor  or  bupati.
Bupatis  will  be  fully  autonomous  and  there  will  be  no  hierarchical  relationship  with  provinces.
They will function solely as the head of the autonomous district government, and be directly and
solely  responsible  to  the  DPRD.  The  district  executive  arm  is  to  be  more  accountable  to  the
district DPRD, which will elect the bupati and his or her deputies with no interference from the
center.

29. 
The  Government  is  drafting  regulations  describing  in  detail  criteria  and  formulas  for
allocating funds from the central Government to local governments, consistent with Law 25/99.
In  addition  to  locally  generated  revenues,  local  governments  will  receive  transfers  through  a
proposed  ‘equalization  fund.’  Resource  transfers  through  the  equalization  fund  will  have  three
components:  (i)  shares  of  central  Government  revenues  from  land  and  building  taxes  and
revenues  from  natural  resources;  (ii)  a  block  grant  General  Allocation  Fund  (GAF),  based  on
factors  including  population  and  poverty  incidence,  that  aims  to  equalize  regional  differences;
and  (iii)  an  earmarked  Special  Allocation  Fund  (SAF)  allocated  for  specific  programs  or
purposes  determined  by  the  sectoral  minister.  GAF  aims  to  balance  interregional  financial
capacity,  considering  local  revenue  raising  potential,  size  of  the  area,  geographic  conditions,
populations, and levels of income. GAF will account for the majority of the funds transferred to
the local governments, totaling at least 25 percent of central Government revenues allocated 90
percent to districts and 10 percent to provinces, as untied block grants. SAF will be allocated to
support projects that fulfill national commitments or priorities or meet special needs. It may not

be used for funding administrative costs, training costs, or similar general operating costs. SAF
allocations  will  be  decided  by  the  technical  ministers  concerned  according  to  availability  of
resources. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will channel SAF directly into the special account of
the region, and the related technical minister will monitor the technical aspects of the project.

30. 
The Government expects decentralization to be implemented in four general phases: (i)
an initiating phase (2001) when functions, staff, and assets are transferred, and when the key
objective  is  to  ensure  continuity  of  services;  (ii)  a  second  phase  (2002–2003)  during  which
decentralization  will  be  completed  in  all  regions,  management  functions  strengthened,  and
broad  programs  aimed  at  upgrading  staff  skills  undertaken;  (iii)  a  consolidation  phase  (2004–
2007) during which the decentralization process will be made irreversible and gaps in the legal
framework corrected; and (iv) a stabilization phase (post-2007) during which regional autonomy
will be further strengthened.

3. 

 Risks and Opportunities of Decentralization

Decentralization  represents  a  major  change–and  challenge–for  the  health  system.
31. 
Although some funds will be earmarked at the central level for specific health activities, the bulk
of resources for health will have to come from the budget of the district (and a small part from
the  budget  of  the  province).  Resource  allocations  among  sectors  will  be  proposed  by  bupatis
and governors, and approved by district or provincial DPRDs respectively. There is a risk that
health services may not be considered among the priorities because the sector does not bring
immediate  measurable  returns.  Strong  and  systematic  advocacy  will  be  needed  to  convince
local decision makers of the need to maintain, and if possible increase, resource allocations for
operational costs of and investment in health services.

32. 
The  weak  managerial  capacity  of  local  health  staff  who  are  not  used  to  planning  and
managing  health  services  without  strong  central  direction  creates  a  risk  of  disruption  in  the
health  services  delivery  system.  There  is  a  need  to  strengthen  local  health  staff,  and  also  to
develop  local  technical  expertise  (e.g.,  university  and  domestic  consultants)  to  support  local
staff. New regulations in health care financing and in personnel management will force districts
and  provinces  to  modify  the  local  health  system  and  introduce  health  sector  reforms  that  suit
their local needs and resources. Immediate issues will be related to health services financing.
Some  poor  districts  will  not  have  the  necessary  resources  to  maintain  basic  health  services.
Government regulations for implementing of Law 25 on Fiscal Balance, providing instructions on
cost-sharing and resources allocations from the central budget, are still being developed. Until
the  districts  (and  provinces)  receive  clear  instructions,  there  will  be  major  uncertainty  in  the
health  sector.  Moreover,  bupatis  and  DPRDs  cannot  make  sensible  allocations  of  local
resources if they do not know exactly how much resources will be available for their district. The
situation is similar at the provincial level.

33. 
The  poor  and  women  may  be  seriously  affected  by  decentralization.  Public  health
services may be disrupted for several reasons: (i) decreased resources for local health services
because  the  health  sector  may  be  given  lower  priority  in  allocation  by  local  parliaments;  (ii)
funding  may  focus  on  curative  health  care  rather  than  on  primary  health  care,  improved
maternal health, and nutrition programs; and (iii) lack of experience of local health staff in health
services planning and management. If public health services do not function normally, better-off
people would probably turn to private health providers; the poor do not have that option. These
risks are compounded by the fact that SPSDP and HNSDP, which funded JPS-BK, are closing
in  2001.  New  and  locally  appropriate  mechanisms  are  needed  to  fund  and  implement

 11

community  outreach  programs  to  ensure  health  care  for  the  poor,  safe  motherhood,  and
nutrition support for malnourished pregnant and lactating women and children under five years.

34. 
Personnel  is  another  issue  that  local  governments  will  have  to  address  rapidly.  About
three quarters of all civil servants are central Government employees, but less than 10 percent
are physically located in the capital. Under decentralization, central Government employees in
districts and provinces are to be transferred to local government payrolls. This may create initial
problems, as central Government staff tend to hold managerial positions desired by local staff.
In  addition,  there  is  a  major  risk  that  districts,  especially  more  remote  districts,  will  lose
experienced  personnel  either  because  financial  incentives  are  not  satisfactory  or  because
opportunities for career progression in the district are limited.

35.  While districts are the main focus of decentralization, some medical problems are more
effectively and cost-efficiently addressed through coordination among neighboring districts and
sometimes  between  provinces.  Public  health  issues,  particularly  infectious  diseases  such  as
malaria and tuberculosis, are not limited by administrative boundaries and coordination across
districts is essential to control them. Districts–now autonomous and no longer subordinate to the
provinces  according  to  the  law–and  provinces  will  have  to  develop  mechanisms  that  ensure
coordination and effectiveness.

Decentralization, however, also offers tremendous opportunities. With local parliaments
36. 
and local administrative and technical staff responsible for resource allocation, local needs can
be given priority. Health services should be able to better answer the demands of the population
with  locally  adapted  solutions  and  increased  efficiency.  The  beneficiaries  also  will  be  in  direct
contact  with  those  who  make  the  decisions.  Greater  beneficiary  involvement  should  improve
transparency. Health sector reforms will have a better chance to succeed because they will be
decided  locally,  based  on  local  circumstances,  and  will  no  longer  be  imposed  from  Jakarta,
uniformly  for  all  regions.  Finally,  mobilization  of  new  financial  resources  for  health  may  be
easier. Resources will not be pooled at a national level, with little opportunity for the prospective
beneficiaries  to  decide  on  their  use.  With  decisions  on  the  use  of  the  resources  made  locally,
local resources should be more easily mobilized.

the  poor,  women,  and  vulnerable  groups.  They  will  participate  in  deciding  and  implementing
appropriate  managerial  and  organizational  changes  and  in  prioritizing  investment  in  the  local
health and family planning sector based on their own assessment, with the technical support of
health  and  BKKBN  staff.  By  emphasizing  the  need  for  better  targeting  of  public  resources  to

 18

vulnerable  groups  and  wide  consultation  in  decision  making,  the  Project  will  help  strengthen
equity and develop consumer choice.

62. 
The  Project  will  cover  all  districts  (50)  and  cities  (12)  in  seven  provinces:  Aceh,  Bali,
Bengkulu,  Riau,  Central  Sulawesi,  North  Sulawesi,  and  Southeast  Sulawesi.30  All  districts  will
participate  in  the  Project  to  facilitate  coordination  and  effectively  address  health  issues  that
extend  beyond  the  district  boundary.  For  this  reason,  only  provinces  with  a  limited  number  of
districts were selected for the Project. The main criterion for selection was a clear commitment
from the district and provincial government to seriously address health sector issues.

63. 
The project provinces and districts are diverse in sociocultural traditions, geography, and
resource base. Aceh is a conservative province. Women's participation rate in the labor force is
low, and fertility rate is high. Ethnically distinct indigenous people live in the central highlands.
With  decentralization,  revenues  from  natural  gas  should  provide  good  resources  to  the  local
governments.  Bali  enjoys  significant  revenue  from  tourism.  With  decentralization,  tourism  tax
revenues  will  not  be  shared  with  the  other  regions.  There  is  scope  for  private  for-profit  health
services, but not in all districts. Paradoxically, local governments in Bali may have problems in
adequately  addressing  health  and  environmental  problems  (such  as  water  supply  and
sanitation),  especially  in  poor  communities  away  from  the  tourist  areas.  Bengkulu,  an  isolated
province with limited resource tax base, was severely hit by an earthquake in June 2000. Riau
has  a  rich  tax  base  from  oil  fields  on  the  mainland  and  a  dynamic  industrial  zone  on  Batam
Island off Singapore. But the province also has large areas of peat swamp characterized by low
fertility  and  difficult  access,  and  small  isolated  islands  in  the  Riau  archipelago  between  the
island of Sumatra, Singapore, and Kalimantan. Indigenous people are found in the mountainous
highlands  along  the  central  Sumatra  mountain  range  and  in  the  Riau  archipelago.  North
Sulawesi  has  an  active  private  not-for-profit  health  sector.  While  some  parts  of  the  province
have  relatively  prosperous  communities,  others  are  very  poor.  Central  Sulawesi  has  a  limited
tax base and small, scattered communities along the narrow coastal strips and in the highland
areas.  It  is  the  most  ethnically  and  linguistically  complex  province  after  Irian  Jaya.  Southeast
Sulawesi comprises a mix of old communities and new settlements. The province is a receiving
area of the overflow from land-short and historically disaster-prone South Sulawesi, and recently
saw a significant increase of internally displaced persons from Maluku.

64. 
The  project  area  is  diverse  in  the  resource  base  available  to  local  governments  for
providing  services,  types  of  communities,  and  existing  infrastructure.  It  will  provide  a  range  of
models  for  resource-rich  and  resource-poor  local  governments  to  address  the  needs  of
relatively  poor  and  nonpoor  communities.  All  project  provinces  are  covered  by  SPSDP  and
HNSDP  (footnote  18).  Aceh  and  Riau  have  participated  in  the  Rural  Health  and  Population
Project  (footnote  22),  and  Bengkulu  is  included  in  the  Family  Health  and  Nutrition  Project
(footnote 23).

1. 

Project Components

65.

sector  reforms;  (iii)  investments  in  health  and  family  planning  services;  and  (iv)  project
management, including implementation, monitoring, and evaluation.

a. 

Advocacy and Capacity Building

66. 
Initial project activities will include advocacy and information campaigns to local decision
makers  (bupatis  and  governors),  the  community,  professional  staff  from  other  sectors,  and
health  staff,  on  decentralization  of  health  services,  social  impact,  gender  and  health,  and
participatory  governance.  Capacity  building  will  start  immediately  to  answer  an  urgent  need.
Capable  and  skilled  professionals  constitute  the  indispensable  foundation  in  developing  and
maintaining  an  efficient  and  equitable  health  system.  Capacity  building  will  include  formal
training,  workshops,  and  study  tours.  The  training  program,  intensive  during  the  first  year,  will
cover  management  and  good  governance:  data  analysis  to  identify  local  needs;  prioritization
and  targeting;  participatory  planning;  budgeting,  accountability,  and  transparency;  social  and
environmental  impact  assessments;  and  monitoring  and  evaluation.  Training  activities  will
continue throughout project implementation. Medical and technical skills will be upgraded.

67.  With  the  use  of  available  information,  field  visits,  and  analysis  of  the  preliminary
proposals submitted by districts, a two-part training program has been developed. To address
common needs, a standard training program has been prepared for all Project areas (Appendix
5). Funds will also be allocated for other training activities based on needs identified locally that
may vary among districts and provinces. Training participants will include health staff and other
civil servants, and representatives of the private sector and civil society as appropriate. For all
training activities, female candidates will be given priority with a view of achieving the target of
50  percent  of  female  participation  in  each  category  of  training  activities.  Study  tours,  short
courses, and academic studies will be subject to approval by ADB.

As  much  as  possible,  training  will  be  provided  on  site.  Trainers  will  be  selected  from
68. 
among MOHSW and BKKBN staff, the private sector and NGOs, professional organizations and
teaching institutions, consultants and other stakeholders. Training activities will be competency
based,  relying  on  experience  and  case  study,  and  using  quality  information,  education,  and
communication material. The Project will help developing collaboration among local universities
and  teaching  institutions  with  expertise  in  public  health.  Investment  in  information  technology
(Internet  connections  and  distance  learning/support)  will  establish  a  network  facilitating
exchange of information and experiences.

69. 
The  Project  will  support  operation  research  studies  that  will  cover  performance
monitoring and evaluation, health service organization, human resource management, impact of
decentralization, health information system, and development of an information network system
among  regions.  These  studies  will  be  proposed  by  the  districts,  provinces,  or  at  central  level,
consolidated by MOHSW and submitted to ADB for approval. The findings will be reviewed by
the  districts,  provinces,  and  the  central  level  and  taken  into  consideration  in  preparing  and
implementing  local  health  sector  reforms.  Domestic  firms  or  academic  institutions  will  be
recruited for operational research studies.

b. 

Adapting Health Services to Local Needs

Initially  the  Project  will  support  consulting  services  for  local  health  sector  analysis  and
70. 
identification  of  locally  suitable  reforms  of  the  health  system,  based  on  national  guidelines.
Various  aspects  of  the  health  system  will  be  reviewed:  the  particular  needs  of  the  poor  and
vulnerable  groups,  health  care  financing,  better  targeting  of  public  resources,  streamlining  of
staff  and  staff  development,  role  of  the  private  sector  (for-profit  and  not  for-profit),  and  public-
private partnership. The existing data collection system and reporting requirements, developed
to answer the needs of a highly centralized system, will need to be adapted to assist the district

 20

authorities and health staff. Subsequently, the Project will support the implementation of locally
identified priority reforms.

71. 
Priority  will  be  given  to  addressing  the  needs  of  the  poor  and  the  vulnerable  groups,
particularly  in  designing  mechanisms  to  sustain  an  efficient  health  safety  net  program.  The
Project will help local authorities transform JPS-BK into a sustainable program, maintaining its
benefits and addressing issues observed during program implementation. Public resources for
health must initially be maintained at least at the existing levels, but local governments need to
find ways of mobilizing new resources in accordance with the national policy.

c. 

Investment in Health and Family Planning

Significant  progress  in  health  and  nutrition  status  can  be  achieved  rapidly  with
72. 
appropriate  investments  in  health  facilities,  equipment,  and  personnel  to  increase  service
quality.  The  Project  will  help  restore  an  effective  and  efficient  health  services  delivery  system
through  judicious  and  cost-efficient  investments  in  health  and  family  planning  services,  based
on local needs. The Project will finance clinical and managerial training, consulting services, civil
works, equipment and material, and operational research.

73. 
Participating districts and provinces developed preliminary proposals for civil works and
equipment  for  health  centers,  district  hospitals,  and  local  training  centers.  The  proposals,  with
technical inputs  and costing from MOHSW, served as the basis for the Project cost estimates
and the indicative procurement packages to be financed by the Project.

d. 

Project Management

74. 
The  project  focus  is  on  developing  local  capacity  at  the  district  and  province  levels  to
prepare  and  implement  health  sector  development  plans  and  to  manage  health  services
delivery. It is necessary for the district and provincial health offices to be directly involved in, and
responsible  for,  project  implementation  to  the  extent  possible.  Realistically,  however,  the
districts  and  provinces  will  require  substantial  strengthening  and  support  before  they  can
discharge  these  tasks  effectively.  Because  of  a  relatively  weak  local  capacity  and  lack  of
experience  in  decision  making  and  project  management,  strong  support  is  needed  for  project
management.

75. 
Funds will be allocated to support implementation at the district, provincial, and central
levels. Project funds will be used to finance the services of project management staff recruited
under  contract  where  needed.  Individual  domestic  and  international  consultants  and  domestic
consulting firms will provide technical support. Regular and intensive supervision and contacts
between districts, provinces, and the central level will be important to prevent mistakes that are
likely to happen with inexperienced staff. The Project will also support independent auditing, and
monitoring  and  evaluation  using  technical  expertise  of  health  professionals  and  active
participation  of  civil  society.  Lessons  and  experience  from  the  JPS-BK  program  will  be
reviewed,  and  independent  monitoring  system  developed  under  HNSDP  will  be  adapted  as
appropriate.

Project Implementation Strategy

To achieve its objectives, the Project will be implemented in a phased manner over five
76. 
years.  During  the  first  phase,  the  Project  will  build  community  support  for  health  and  family
planning  in  the  districts  through  advocacy  and  information  campaigns,  and  will  strengthen

 21

development plans incorporating appropriate investments and reforms. In the second phase, the
Project  will  finance  investments  in  health  and  family  planning,  and  support  implementation  of

districts  in  Bengkulu  that  give  priority  to  rehabilitation  of  earthquake-damaged  infrastructure)

 B. 

Project Sustainability

31

118.  Two factors are important to ensure sustainability of health service delivery: greater cost-
efficiency  in  resource  allocation  and  increased  resources  mobilization.  A  major  benefit  of
decentralization  is  the  local  participation  in  identifying  the  needs  and  developing  appropriate
solutions,  taking  into  consideration  local  conditions.  With  adequate  technical  skills,  significant
efficiency  gains  in  health  services  planning  and  management  can  be  realized.  Rationalizing
personnel and increasing public-private partnership are among the main issues that districts and
provinces must address, in preparing their reform proposals.

119.  Project  investments  in  advocacy  and  capacity  building  will  be  essential  to  ensure
sustainability.  These  activities  target  not  only  health  staff  but  also  nonhealth  stakeholders
including  members  of  the  local  governments.  People  responsible  for  identifying  priorities  and
allocating  resources  in  the  districts  and  provinces  will  benefit  from  the  training  activities,
technical  support  from  experts,  and  continuous  policy  dialogue  with  ADB.  This  will  increase
allocation efficiency.

120.  Primary  health  care37  is  a  very  cost-effective  strategy  for  health  service  delivery.  The
Project  aims  to  guarantee  quality  primary  health  care  services  for  the  poor.  Because  primary
health  care  services  have  large  positive  externalities  and  are  most  beneficial  to  the  poor,  it  is
inappropriate to insist on cost-recovery for such services.38 Cost recovery inhibits not only poor
people’s  access  to  essential  health  services;  it  also  imposes  large  administrative  costs.
However,  the  Project  emphasizes  resource  mobilization  for  health  services,  and  will  finance
training activities, technical expertise and, when appropriate, implementation of reforms that will
help mobilize new resources in the districts and provinces. In particular, the development of a
health  insurance  system  or  a  managed  care  system  is  a  priority  of  the  Government  and  the
national  health  policy.  Better  public-private  partnership  also  will  get  the  private  sector  more
involved in health care financing. Advocacy and policy dialogue, increased efficiency in resource
allocation,  and  mobilization  of  new  resources  for  the  health  sector  are  the  main  mechanisms
that will ensure sustainability of project investments.

medical  wastes).  The  IEE  report  and  environmental  management  and  monitoring  plans
approved  by  the  Government  will  be  submitted  to  ADB  before  any  civil  works  are  approved.
Some districts have proposed to address, under the Project, sanitation and environment issues
that  have  a  positive  impact  on  health.  With  the  achievement  of  the  objectives  of  the  Project,
positive environmental impacts will occur through improved sanitation.

 D. 

Social Dimensions

32

122.  The rationale and the design of the Project explain its high social value indicated by the
initial  poverty  impact  assessment  (Appendix  13).  The  Government  is  the  main  provider  of
modern  health  services  for  the  poor,  women,  and  children;  any  disruption  of  the  public  health
care delivery system will mainly affect these groups. While the better-off will probably be able to
afford  the  services  of  private  providers,  the  poor  will  face  major  problems.  Focus  group
discussions  with  women  revealed  their  particular  concern  with  the  cessation  of  the  JPS-BK
activities as the program closes at the end of 2001, and possible disruption in the availability of
health  care  services  and  contraceptives.  The  immediate  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  ensure
technical support to the districts to maintain normal health services delivery. This support will be
most  necessary  during  the  difficult  initial  phase  of  decentralization,  which  explains  the
Government’s request for fast processing of the Project.

123.  Districts  will  pay  particular  attention  to  accessibility  of  health  services  for  the  poor  and
will review the JPS-BK program to ensure continuation of those elements that have shown the
greatest impact on the poor. Paradoxically during the crisis, access to essential services for the
poor was protected with the establishment of JPS-BK. But this program was financed mainly by
external  resources.  Appropriate  mechanisms  must  be  found  to  maintain  the  benefits  of  the
program  while  ensuring  its  continuity  and  sustainability.  Reorientation  of  JPS-BK  is  a  project
priority.

124.  Family  planning  and  reproductive  health,  of  greatest  concern  to  women,  are  primary
project  components.  With  quality  family  planning  accessible  to  everybody  and  especially  the
poor,  families  are  able  to  space  births  and  ensure  a  harmonious  development  of  all  the
members. Women’s option to control their fertility gives them greater control over their destiny.
Women also will benefit from all training activities. Priority will be given to women trainees with a
view to achieve 50 percent of women trainees and fellowship candidates. This recommendation
will benefit women in the local community and provide them with greater opportunities for career
advancement.

125.  The project districts, particularly in Riau, Central Sulawesi and Southeast Sulawesi, have
significant  numbers  of  indigenous  groups  almost  entirely  dependent  on  the  public  health  care
system.  Their  continued  access  to  health  care  depends  on  the  degree  to  which  local  health
services and decision makers give priority to the needs of the poor and vulnerable communities
under decentralization.

126.  With an advocacy campaign targeting local authorities and capacity-building activities for
health staff, the populations in the project area will have some guarantee that the decentralized
public health services will continue to function normally. Capacity building and investment in the
health sector will have an immediate impact on the quality of the health services and, hopefully,
on  patient  satisfaction.  Better  quality  health  services  will  result  in  better  health  and  nutrition
status for the local population.

E. 

Risks and Safeguards

127.  Although decentralization is required by law, its rapid implementation carries major risks
of disruption of public services for these reasons: regulations are not ready or well understood,
instructions  can  be  misinterpreted,  and  there  was  no  time  to  build  up  local  capacity.  Project
activities will be planned and implemented by local staff with little or no experience, who are not
used  to  taking  initiative  or  accepting  responsibility.  The  Project  was  designed  to  reduce  these

 33

risks.  The  Project  is  process-oriented  and  will  be  implemented  in  two  phases,  emphasizing
capacity building in the first phase.  Investment and reform proposals will be confirmed only at
the  end  of  the  first  phase.  Although  preliminary  investment  proposals  have  been  prepared  by
the  districts,  these  proposals  must  be  reviewed  and  refined  and  submitted  with  appropriate
justification  for  formal  endorsement  by  the  Government  and  ADB.  This  two-step  approach  will
ensure identification and selection of cost-efficient investments. The continuous participation of
the  local  community  in  preparation,  implementation,  and  monitoring,  through  the  DHC,  will
increase a local sense of ownership, facilitate sustainability of activities, and guarantee that the
Project effectively benefits the targeted beneficiaries.

128.  Counterpart funding for project activities has been carefully discussed, but remains a risk
due to the prevailing economic difficulties and because Law 25/99 limits the rights of the central
Government to earmark funds that will be used in the districts and the provinces. In accordance
with  Laws  22/99  and  25/99,  project  funds  will  be  channeled  through  SAF  /  GAF.  Project
resources  have  been  allocated  to  ensure  that  delay  in  counterpart  funding  will  not  prevent
implementation  of  essential  project  activities.

A. 

Objective and Scope

1.
The Project will be accompanied by technical assistance (TA): Support for Health Sector
Policy  Reforms.  For  several  years,  there  has  been  continuing  dialogue  between  the  Asian
Development Bank (ADB) and the Government on the need for health sector policy reform and
assessment  of  reform  options.1  The  dialogue  intensified  when  the  economic  crisis  affected
Indonesia in 1997-1998. The Ministry of Health (now the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare
[MOHSW])  rapidly  set  up  a  social  safety  net  program  (JPS-BK)  to  protect  access  to  and
availability of essential health services with ADB support.2 MOHSW and ADB developed policy
matrices  that  identified  urgently  needed  reforms.  The  full  implementation  of  decentralization
starting in 2001 demands that reforms be implemented, but also offers new opportunities.

2.
Health sector reforms are necessary to help the Indonesian health system adapt to the
new social, political, and economic environment. Many aspects of the health system need to be
reviewed to assess whether they are still appropriate in the present context or whether changes
should  be  introduced  to  improve  effectiveness  and  efficiency.  These  aspects  include  health
system  organization,  role  of  MOHSW,  quality  assurance,  health  care  financing,  public-private
partnerships,  family  planning  program  and  reproductive  health,  staff  management  and,  most
important,  how  the  health  system  can  ensure  that  the  poor  and  the  vulnerable  groups  have

SOCIAL AND POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT

A. 

Introduction

Decentralization  presents  great  opportunities  for  improving  the  delivery  of  health
1.
services, and the transition period shapes the form of health service delivery for the long term.
In the wake of change and adjustment during this period, it is important to ensure that the needs
of the poor and vulnerable, who tend to be less vocal, are not overlooked and that mechanisms
to protect this needs are developed.

2.
The project area is diverse in terms of the resource base that the local government has
to provide with services, types of communities, and level of existing infrastructure, and therefore
reflects  the  range  of  diverse  conditions  under  which  decentralization  is  taking  place.  It  will
provide  models  for  addressing  the  needs  of  local  governments  serving  poor  and  nonpoor
communities.  The  principal  criterion  for  selection  is  a  clear  commitment  from  the  district  and
provincial  government  to  address  health  sector  issues.  Despite  the  district-level  focus  of  the
project,  all  districts  in  the  selected  provinces  are  included  in  the  program  for  effective
coordination of health services that extend beyond the district boundary.

3.
The project provinces and districts are diverse in sociocultural traditions, geography, and
resource base. Aceh is a conservative province. Women's participation rate in the labor force is
low, and fertility rate is high. Ethnically distinct indigenous people live in the central highlands.
With  decentralization,  revenues  from  natural  gas  should  provide  good  resources  to  the  local
governments.  Bali  enjoys  significant  revenue  from  tourism  but  under  decentralization,  tourism,
tax revenues are not shared with the regions. In the health sector, there is scope for private for-
profit health services, but not in all districts. Paradoxically, local governments in Bali may have
problems  in  adequately  addressing  health  and  environmental  problems  (such  as  water  supply
and  sanitation),  especially  for  poor  communities  away  from  the  tourist  areas.  Bengkulu,  an
isolated  province  with  limited  resource  tax  base,  was  severely  hit  by  an  earthquake  in  June
2000. Riau has a rich tax base from oil fields on the mainland and a dynamic industrial zone on
Batam Island off Singapore. But the province also has large areas of peat swamp characterized
by low fertility and difficult access, and small isolated islands in the Riau archipelago between
the  island  of  Sumatra,  Singapore,  and  Kalimantan.  Indigenous  peoples  are  found  in  the
mountainous highlands along the central Sumatra mountain range and in the Riau archipelago.
North  Sulawesi  has  an  active  not-for-profit  private  health  sector.  While  some  parts  of  the
province have relatively prosperous communities, others are very poor. Central Sulawesi has a
limited  tax  base  and  small,  scattered  communities  along  the  narrow  coastal  strips  and  in  the
highland  areas.  It  is  the  most  ethnically  and  linguistically  complex  province  after  Irian  Jaya.
Southeast  Sulawesi  comprises  a  mix  of  old  communities  and  new  settlements.  Southeast
Sulawesi comprises a mix of old communities and new settlements, as it receives the overflow
from land-short and historically disaster-prone South Sulawesi.

9.

Poor women are more vulnerable to the consequences of ill health and are less able to guard
the health of their children. Poor health also diminishes learning and working capabilities, and
reduces a person’s competitiveness in the labor market.

14. Women’s access to health care is important to women’s direct health care needs as well

3. 

Decentralization

15.
Decentralization  creates  new  risks  for  public  health,  particularly  for  women’s  heath
issues, as funding of health sector programs will depend on the priorities of local officials. While
decentralization  can  ensure  that  health  programs  are  more  focused  on  local  needs,  local
officials, especially members of the local parliament must be educated in health care issues. For
this  reason,  the  decentralized  health  services  provides  a  strong  emphasis  on  advocacy  and
training  of  local  decision  makers.  In  addition,  to  ensure  that  programs  are  not  driven  by  the
priorities of the technocrats, the Project provides for preparation of district health plans through
a  participatory  process.  The  district  committee  will  be  established  to  include  women  and  men
representatives  from  the  communities.  The  task  of  the  health  committee  is  to  review  existing
health services and access to them by the poor, nonpoor, women and men; and to identify local
health  needs  by  gender.  The  Project  will  provide  better  access  to  health  services  to  the  poor,
women,  and  children  by  strengthening  basic  health  programs,  reproductive  health,  family
planning, and nutrition.

C. 

Project Design Components to Promote Poverty Targeting

16.
A number of measures were built into the design of the Project to ensure that the needs
of women, the poor, and vulnerable groups including indigenous people are given priority and
that the poor have disproportionate access to the benefits.

(i) 

District  proposals  will  be  evaluated  for  funding  according  to  several  criteria
including  how  the  proposed  investment  will  benefit  the  poor,  women,  and  the

vulnerable. Training and technical support will be provided during the first phase
of  project  implementation  to  assist  health  staff  and  the  community  in  assessing
and reporting the impact of the proposal on the poor.

Proposals that include the needs of the local poor and vulnerable groups will be
given  priority.  Priority  will  be  given  in  financing  primary  health  care  services,
family planning, and availability of contraceptives.

Advocacy  and  information  campaigns  will  sensitize  local  decision  makers  and
members  of  civil  society.  Training  will  sensitize  local  health  staff  to  the  specific
needs of the poor and vulnerable groups.

Advocacy, information campaigns, and training activities will highlight the special
needs  of  women  and  the  poor.  The  Project  will  finance  consulting  services  and
training  on  gender  and  health,  including  appropriate  information,  education  and
communication  materials.  Maternal  mortality  and  morbidity,  and  reproductive
health  services  will  be  given  special  attention.  Benchmark  data  and  data
collected for project monitoring and performance evaluation will be disaggregated
by gender.

Training activities target a gender balance of 50 percent female. This will not only
improve  skills  and  qualification  of  female  health  staff  but  also  ensure  that  more
female  health  staff  are  ready  to  assist  and  answer  the  particular  needs  of
women.

Policy  dialogue  will  emphasize  better  targeting  of  public  subsidies,  and  local
mechanisms will be developed to continue the health safety net program linking
public subsidies to the poor and vulnerable groups.
